Description: Fragmentary pink granite statue, only the lower legs and part of the back pillar now remaining. The statue is broken from the knees, with a thin ridge delineated along the front of the calves. The left leg advances forward ahead of the right leg. The statue is also broken from the ankles. On the right side of the stone is a small section of modern writing in ink, which gives details about the object’s provenance. At the reverse is a portion of a broad back-pillar. There are numerous chips across the stone surface, particularly along the lower left and right side and across the back-pillar. The object is attached to a modern rectangular base.
Curator's comments: This partial figure was excavated at the site of Buto by the Egypt Exploration Society in 1968. The writing on the right side of the stone refers to the year of excavation and location where the figure was found – Site G sits towards the south of the excavation area. General Sources: D. Charlesworth, 1969. 'TeIl el-Farain: the Industrial Site, 1968', Journal of Egyptian Archaeology 55, p. 23-30. D. Charlesworth, 1970. 'The TeIl el-Farain Expedition, 1969', Journal of Egyptian Archaeology 56, p. 19-28. M.V. Seton-Williams, 1969. 'The Tell el-Farain Expedition, 1968', Journal of Egyptian Archaeology 55, p. 5-22.
